 java.util.LinkedHashMap identifyMultilingual(java.io.File testFile)
          Some points about generalised multilingual identification:
- Not possible to use techniques like maximum entropy because there is unlikely to be any data for training
- Limited ambiguity hypothesis: There are likely to be only two or three languages in a document is most cases
- Single word problem: There are likely to be single (isolated) words in a language different from the surrounding words
which means sophisticated context based techniques are unlikely to work
- The above also means that we have to operate at the character (or byte) level, rather than word or word sequence level
- There can be unresolvable ambiguity because the same word may belong to many languages and those languages
might be using the same or almost same encoding
- Different techniques can be applied depending on whether we assume that single isolated words will occur in the
the document or whether there will only be long sequences in the same language
- If we assume the presence of single isolated words, the problem essentially reduces to identifying each word separately
-- We can take the context into account to a limited extent, using a threshold and weighted sum
- Otherwise, the problem is of determining the points at which language changes, along with monolingual identification
-- This can be done by calculating sudden drops in probabilities of word n-grams based on the character based n-grams model for the current sequence whose langauge we have previously determined
-- One problem here is to find the language of the first sequence
- We can also have a dominant language assumption, which will affect other things above
- We could also try to guess dynamically whether the single/isolated word case holds or not


There are four steps, each can be considered a different problem:
1.

train

public void train()
Training is done for pairs of language and encoding. These pairs and their corresponding directory names (which have the training files/directories) are read from a properties file. The left column has the language and encoding names separated by double colon (::). The right column gives the path.

identifyMultilingual

public java.util.LinkedHashMap identifyMultilingual(java.io.File testFile)
Some points about generalised multilingual identification:
- Not possible to use techniques like maximum entropy because there is unlikely to be any data for training
- Limited ambiguity hypothesis: There are likely to be only two or three languages in a document is most cases
- Single word problem: There are likely to be single (isolated) words in a language different from the surrounding words
which means sophisticated context based techniques are unlikely to work
- The above also means that we have to operate at the character (or byte) level, rather than word or word sequence level
- There can be unresolvable ambiguity because the same word may belong to many languages and those languages
might be using the same or almost same encoding
- Different techniques can be applied depending on whether we assume that single isolated words will occur in the
the document or whether there will only be long sequences in the same language
- If we assume the presence of single isolated words, the problem essentially reduces to identifying each word separately
-- We can take the context into account to a limited extent, using a threshold and weighted sum
- Otherwise, the problem is of determining the points at which language changes, along with monolingual identification
-- This can be done by calculating sudden drops in probabilities of word n-grams based on the character based n-grams model for the current sequence whose langauge we have previously determined
-- One problem here is to find the language of the first sequence
- We can also have a dominant language assumption, which will affect other things above
- We could also try to guess dynamically whether the single/isolated word case holds or not


There are four steps, each can be considered a different problem:
1. Enumerating the languages the document is guessed to be in
2. Finding the top t most likely languages for each word
3. Based on the languages of the preceding and succeeding word(s), finalising the most likely (one) language for each word
4. Marking up portions of the text with their guessed languages

Evaluation: There can five measures, correspoding the above sub-problems:
1. Precision of language enumeration
2. Precision of single word identification (isolated)
3. Precision of single word identification (context based)
4. Precision of markup

Returns:
Strings from text as keys and langEncs as values.

enumerateLangEncs

public java.util.LinkedHashMap enumerateLangEncs(java.io.File testFile)
Uses

Returns:
langEncs (Strings) keys and scores as values, sorted by scores (best first).

identifyWords

public java.util.Vector identifyWords(java.lang.String[] words,
                                      int topLangEncs)
Returns a Vector of LinkedHashMaps, where each LinkedHashMap has langEnc as the key and score as the value.
Sorted (optionally top t) langEncs (by score) are returned.
